facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 496 of 1966 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 10, 1964 of the Mysore High Court in Regular Appeal No. 75 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 496 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 10, 1964 of the Mysore High Court in Regular Appeal No. 75 of 1956.

facts.text: In 1820 the Nizam of Hyderabad granted a jagir to Nawab Salar Jung I including Madlapur village in Raichur district.

anchor.surface_text: In 1820 the Nizam of Hyderabad granted a jagir, the terms whereof do not appear from the record before us, to his Prime Minister known as Nawab Salar Jung T. This jagir consisted of many villages in the district of Raichur one of them being Madlapur on the bank of the river Tungabhadra.

facts.text: In 1930 Nawab Salar Jung III granted an island comprising S. Nos. 154, 312 and 313 with a granite hillock of 250 ft. height and Ac. 290-00 to Swami Nijananda, predecessor-in-interest of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1930 the successor of the original grantee of the jagir, Nawab Salar Jung III made a grant of an island in that village comprising S. Nos. 154, 312 and 313 with a hillock rising to a height of 250 ft. and measuring Ac. 290-00 in favour of one Swami Nijananda, the predecessor-in-interest of the respondent.

facts.text: The land was notified for acquisition under Hyderabad Land Acquisition Act on February 3, 1946 for Tungabhadra Project to gather granite for dam construction.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1946 the entire area covered by the grant to Swami Nijananda was proposed to be acquired for an irrigation and hydroelectric project known as the Tungabhadra Project which had been embarked upon by the Governments of Hyderabad and Madras States. The purpose of acquisition was the gathering of granite stone for the construction of a dam across the river Tungabhadra.

facts.text: Final notification for acquisition made on June 16, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The acquisition proceedings were completed pursuant to a final notification made on June 16, 1947 followed by an award by the Land Acquisition Officer on July 24, 1950.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer made award on July 24, 1950 awarding Rs. 31,260-8-0 total compensation, disallowing claim for granite hillock.

anchor.surface_text: The acquisition proceedings were completed pursuant to a final notification made on June 16, 1947 followed by an award by the Land Acquisition Officer on July 24, 1950. Before the Land Acquisition Officer two claims were put forward, one on behalf of the respondent Swami Satyananda and the other by Nawab Salar Jung III.

facts.text: Swami Satyananda claimed Rs. 29,91,600 compensation before Land Acquisition Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of Swami Satyananda was for Rs. 29,91,600. The Land Acquisition Officer awarded Rs. 31,260-8-0 as the total compensation disallowing the claim in respect of the granite hillock on the ground that it was not covered by the grant to Swami Nijananda.

facts.text: District Judge enhanced compensation to Rs. 48,892 exclusive of statutory allowance and interest.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge to whom reference was made under the Land Acquisition Act enhanced the compensation to Rs. 48,892 exclusive of statutory allowance and interest.

facts.text: District Judge found the rock situated within the patta land of the claimant.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the issues framed by the District Judge related to the respondents claim to a right in the quarry and also to the situs thereof i.e. as to whether it was within the patta land belonging to the claimant. He found that the rock was situated within the patta land of the claimant

facts.text: District Judge held claimant had no right to minerals and quarries based on Farmans Exs. A-21, A-22, Section 2(d) Mines Act, Section 3 Hyderabad Land Revenue Act.

anchor.surface_text: but with regard to the quarry rights he took the view on the basis of two Farmans of the Nizam Exs. A-21 and A-22 and Section 2 d  of the Mines Act and Section 3 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act that the claimant had no right to the minerals and quarries.

facts.text: Mysore High Court judgment dated August 10, 1964 held that the grant to Nawab Salar Jung included granite rights and pattas conferred them; granite not a mineral.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 10, 1964 of the Mysore High Court in Regular Appeal No. 75 of 1956.

facts.text: All jagirs including Nawab Salar Jung's were abolished during pendency of acquisition proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: But as all jagirs including that of Nawab Salar Jung were abolished during the pendency of the acquisition proceedings, the claim for compensation by Nawab Salar Jung III also disappeared.

facts.text: Patta Ex.49 for S.Nos. 312 and 313 granted to Narasimha Bharati Swamy from 1331 Fasli for cultivation or grazing, excluding trees and paramboke.

anchor.surface_text: The patta for S. Nos. 312 and 313 was marked as Ex. 49 in this case. It contains various columns including those for the name of Khatedar... The patta bearing S. Nos. 312- 313 may be made in the name of the applicant Narsimha Bharati Swamy from 1331 Fasli.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that patta did not confer sub-soil or mining rights; only for cultivation or grazing cattle.

anchor.surface_text: The patta Ex. 49 in this case amply demonstrates that what was in contemplation of the parties at the time of the grant in .1930 was the cultivation thereof or grazing cattle thereon.

facts.text: Supreme Court held granite is a mineral.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in our view possible to hold otherwise than that granite is a mineral.

facts.text: Land area: hillock Ac. 290-00, S.No.154 paramboke, 312:109a13g, 313:13a13g.

anchor.surface_text: with a hillock rising to a height of 250 ft. and measuring Ac. 290-00 in favour of one Swami Nijananda

facts.text: District Judge did not record finding on whether jagir included mining rights.

anchor.surface_text: He did not record any finding as to whether the jagir granted by the Nizam included the mining rights and whether the patta granted by the jagirdar conferred the same rights on the claimant

facts.text: High Court held Farmans A-21 A-22 did not affect subsisting mineral rights of jagirdar.

anchor.surface_text: It however held, differing from the District Judge, that the Farmans Exs. A-21 and A-22 did no more than explain the provisions of Section 63 of the Land Revenue Act and did not affect any subsisting rights in the minerals if they belonged to the jagirdar.

facts.text: High Court refused to entertain contention that 1820 grant did not include granite rights, raised first time by Advocate-General.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was not willing to entertain the contention raised by the Advocate-General for the first time that the grant did not include the right to granite in the hillock.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no presumption that Nizam parted with mineral rights to jagirdar or jagirdar to grantee.

anchor.surface_text: There is no scope for any presumption that the Nizam had parted with the mineral rights to the jagirdar or that the jagirdar had done so in his turn.

facts.text: Settlement Department letter stated land for grazing cattle, unfit for cultivation, Government right over tamarind trees.

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to the letter issued by the Superintendent, Settlement Department, Salar Jung Estate where the petition for grant of patta of land of Bolur Gedda by Narasimha Bharati Swamy mentioned as one for the purpose of grazing cattle.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court decree on minerals/quarry rights and restored District Judge's judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.

issues.text: whether the respondent was entitled to sub-soil rights by virtue of the pattas granted in favour of his predecessor-in-interest by Nawab Salar Jung III of Hyderabad and as a consequence thereof became entitled to compensation claimed by him for acquisition of a large block of land containing a hillock of granite which was required for the Tungabhadra Project and was notified for acquisition under the Hyderabad Land Acquisition Act

anchor.surface_text: The main question involved in this appeal is whether the respondent was entitled to sub-soil rights by virtue of the pattas granted in favour of his predecessor-in-interest by Nawab Salar Jung III of Hyderabad and as a consequence thereof became entitled to compensation claimed by him for acquisition of a large block of land containing a hillock of granite which was required for the Tungabhadra Project and was notified for acquisition under the Hyderabad Land Acquisition Act

issues.text: whether the claimant had a right to the minerals and quarries

anchor.surface_text: He found that the rock was situated within the patta land of the claimant but with regard to the quarry rights he took the view on the basis of two Farmans of the Nizam Exs. A-21 and A-22 and Section 2 d  of the Mines Act and Section 3 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act that the claimant had no right to the minerals and quarries.

issues.text: as to whether it was within the patta land belonging to the claimant

anchor.surface_text: Two of the issues framed by the District Judge related to the respondents claim to a right in the quarry and also to the situs thereof i.e. as to whether it was within the patta land belonging to the claimant. He found that the rock was situated within the patta land of the claimant

issues.text: whether the jagir granted by the Nizam included the mining rights

anchor.surface_text: He did not record any finding as to whether the jagir granted by the Nizam included the mining rights and whether the patta granted by the jagirdar conferred the same rights on the claimant in view of his conclusion on the points of law urged that mining rights were in the exclusive ownership of the Nizam.

issues.text: whether the patta granted by the jagirdar conferred the same rights on the claimant

anchor.surface_text: He did not record any finding as to whether the jagir granted by the Nizam included the mining rights and whether the patta granted by the jagirdar conferred the same rights on the claimant

issues.text: whether the grant to Nawab Salar Jung included the right to granite in the hillock

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court the question as to whether the grant to Nawab Salar Jung did or did not include the granite in the hillock was never raised at any stage and it was assumed by every one that the grant to Nawab Salar Jung included the right to granite and that right was a subsisting right even while the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act 1907 was enacted.
It is not in our view possible to hold otherwise than that granite is a mineral.

issues.text: the effect of the Farmans or of Section 63 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act

anchor.surface_text: In our view it is not necessary to consider the effect of the Farmans or of Section 63 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act. It was for the respondent to establish his claim to minerals or quarry rights by putting forward proof of the grant thereof by the Nizam to Salar Jung

arguments.claim: the patta did not confer sub-soil or mining rights; only for cultivation or grazing cattle

anchor.surface_text: The patta for S. Nos. 312 and 313 was marked as Ex. 49 in this case. It contains various columns including those for the name of Khatedar... The patta Ex. 49 in this case amply demonstrates that what was in contemplation of the parties at the time of the grant in .1930 was the cultivation thereof or grazing cattle thereon.

arguments.claim: sub-soil rights are not to be treated as having been conveyed by implication in grants of surface rights

anchor.surface_text: A long line of decisions of the Judicial Committee of Privy Council relating mainly to the grants of land and leases by the Zamindars in Bengal makes it amply clear that sub-soil rights are not to be treated as having been conveyed by implication in grants of surface rights to tenure-holders pattidars lessees etc.
It is not in our view possible to hold otherwise than that granite is a mineral. According to Halsburys Laws of England There is no general definition of the word mineral.

arguments.qualifiers: not in our view possible to hold otherwise

arguments.claim: granite hillock not covered by the grant to Swami Nijananda

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 29,91,600. The Land Acquisition Officer awarded Rs. 31,260-8-0 as the total companypensation disallo

arguments.court_reasoning: District Judge found rock situated within patta land

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider the effect of the Farmans or of Section 63 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our view it is not necessary to consider the effect of the Farmans or of Section 63 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act. It was for the respondent to establish his claim to minerals or quarry rights by putting forward proof of the grant thereof by the Nizam to Salar Jung

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on respondent to prove grant of mineral rights; failure to produce evidence makes consideration unnecessary.

holdings.text: There is no scope for any presumption that the Nizam had parted with the mineral rights to the jagirdar or that the jagirdar had done so in his turn.

anchor.surface_text: There is no scope for any presumption that the Nizam had parted with the mineral rights to the jagirdar or that the jagirdar had done so in his turn. Even assuming that the Nizam conferred the right of minerals in the land or to quarry for granite therein to Nawab Salar Jung I,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of parting with sovereign mineral rights; claimant must prove express grant.

holdings.text: The patta Ex. 49 demonstrates that the grant was for cultivation or grazing cattle thereon, not conferring sub-soil or mining rights.

anchor.surface_text: The patta Ex. 49 in this case amply demonstrates that what was in contemplation of the parties at the time of the grant in .1930 was the cultivation thereof or grazing cattle thereon. The grantor was even careful to reserve the right to fruit-baring trees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of patta, settlement letters, and reservations show surface use only; no mention of mining.

holdings.text: Sub-soil rights are not to be treated as having been conveyed by implication in grants of surface rights to tenure-holders, pattidars, lessees etc.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle from Privy Council cases applied generally beyond zamindari; purpose and terms of grant control.
Commercial and mining usage per Halsbury and Welsh Granite Co. case; prevails over scientific definition.

holdings.text: The claim to compensation on the basis of the sub-soil rights to the hillock must therefore be negatived.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no proof of mineral grant in chain, patta surface only, granite mineral hence excluded.

holdings.text: The decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on presumptions, granite not mineral, Farmans effect; District Judge correct per statutes/Farmans.

precedents.citation: Hari Narayan Singh v Sriram Chakravarti 1

anchor.surface_text: Hari Narayan Singh v Sriram Chakravarti 1 . There the dispute was as to the right to minerals lying under a village called Petena situate within the zamindari of the first appellant.

precedents.case_name: Hari Narayan Singh v Sriram Chakravarti
precedents.cited_proposition: zamindar raja is presumed to be the owner of the underground rights in absence of evidence that he parted with them
precedents.cited_holding: he must be presumed to be the owner of the underground rights thereto appertaining in the absence of evidence that he ever parted with them, and no such evidence has been produced

precedents.citation: Durga Prasad Singh v. Braja Nath Bose 1

anchor.surface_text: Durga Prasad Singh v. Braja Nath Bose 1 was a case where the zamindar of a permanently settled estate who asked for a declaration of his right to minerals as against a lessee from a digwar tenure holder.

precedents.case_name: Durga Prasad Singh v Braja Nath Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: digwar had no proprietary right in underground minerals absent evidence zamindar parted with mineral rights
precedents.cited_holding: the latter could not be held to have any proprietary right in the minerals

precedents.citation: Girdhari Singh v. Megh Lai Pandey 2

anchor.surface_text: Girdhari Singh v. Megh Lai Pandey 2 the question before the Board was whether a mokarari lease of land with all rights carried a right to the subjecent minerals in a permanently settled estate.

precedents.case_name: Girdhari Singh v Megh Lai Pandey
precedents.cited_proposition: unless express or plainly implied grant of mineral rights in lease, they remain reserved to zamindar
precedents.cited_holding: unless there be by the terms of the lease an express or plainly implied grant of those rights, they remain reserved to the zamindar as part of the zamindari

precedents.citation: Sashi Bhushan Misra v. Jyoti Prasahad Singh Deo 3

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships referred to the decisions mentioned above as also to that of Sashi Bhushan Misra v. Jyoti Prasahad Singh Deo 3 and adopted the principle p. 249 when a grant is made by a zamindar of a tenure at a fixed rent although the tenure may be permanent, heritable, and transferable, minerals will not be held to have formed part of the grant in the absence of express evidence to that effect.

precedents.case_name: Sashi Bhushan Misra v Jyoti Prasahad Singh Deo
precedents.cited_proposition: minerals not part of grant of tenure at fixed rent absent express evidence

precedents.citation: Govinda Narayan Singh v. Sham Lai Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Most of the above cases were referred to again by the, Board in Govinda Narayan Singh v. Sham Lai Singh 1 where after noting the earlier cases the Board concluded that in the case of any claim against the zamindar to the lands which were included at the permanent settlement the burden of proof is upon the claimant.

precedents.case_name: Govinda Narayan Singh v Sham Lai Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: burden of proof on claimant against zamindar for lands included at permanent settlement
precedents.cited_holding: in the case of any claim against the zamindar to the lands which were included at the permanent settlement the burden of proof is upon the claimant

precedents.citation: Bejoy Singh Dudhoria v. Surendra Narayan Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to Bejoy Singh Dudhoria v. Surendra Narayan Singh 1 where the Board held that the grant of a patni lease by a zamindar of his zamindari lands including all interest therein, and jalkar, banker, falkar, beels and jhils at an annual jama containing a stipulation that the grantee should not cut trees or excavate a tank was only consistent with the theory that the lessee and those claiming under him were not entitled to excavate the soil for the purpose of making bricks and that there was no transfer of the property in the soil.

precedents.case_name: Bejoy Singh Dudhoria v Surendra Narayan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: patni lease with no-cut trees or excavate stipulation means no right to excavate soil
precedents.cited_holding: there was no transfer of the property in the soil

precedents.citation: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Duvvuru Balarami Reddy 2

anchor.surface_text: We may also note that in State of Andhra Pradesh v. Duvvuru Balarami Reddy 2 where the respondents had obtained mining leases for mining mica from the owners of a certain shrotriem village it was held that shrotriemdars had no rights in the minerals and the leases granted by them to the respondent had no legal effect.

precedents.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v Duvvuru Balarami Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: shrotriemdars have no rights in minerals; leases by them ineffective
precedents.cited_holding: shrotriemdars had no rights in the minerals and the leases granted by them to the respondent had no legal effect

precedents.citation: Attorney General v. Welsh Granite Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference is there made to the case of Attorney General v. Welsh Granite Co. 1 where granite was held to be included under the reservation of minerals in the Enclosure Act which reserved all mines, minerals, ores, coal, limestone, and slate to the Crown.

precedents.case_name: Attorney General v Welsh Granite Co
precedents.cited_proposition: granite is included in the word minerals
precedents.cited_holding: granite was held to be included under the reservation of minerals

No Implied Conveyance of Sub-soil Rights support

anchor.surface_text: The claim to companypensation on the basis of the sub-soil rights to the hillock must therefore be negatived and the appeal allowed. In the result the decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.

outcome.relief_summary: Respondent's claim to compensation for sub-soil rights, minerals or quarry rights in the hillock negatived; High Court decree set aside; District Judge's judgment and order restored on that point
directions: decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights set aside
judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored

anchor.surface_text: In our view it is not necessary to consider the effect of the Farmans or of Section 63 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act. It was for the respondent to establish his claim to minerals or quarry rights by putting forward proof of the grant thereof by the Nizam to Salar Jung

The claim to companypensation on the basis of the sub-soil rights to the hillock must therefore be negatived and the appeal allowed. In the result the decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.

anchor.surface_text: There is no scope for any presumption that the Nizam had parted with the mineral rights to the jagirdar or that the jagirdar had done so in his turn. Even assuming that the Nizam conferred the right of minerals in the land or to quarry for granite therein to Nawab Salar Jung I,

The claim to companypensation on the basis of the sub-soil rights to the hillock must therefore be negatived and the appeal allowed. In the result the decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.

anchor.surface_text: The patta Ex. 49 in this case amply demonstrates that what was in contemplation of the parties at the time of the grant in .1930 was the cultivation thereof or grazing cattle thereon. The grantor was even careful to reserve the right to fruit-baring trees.

The claim to companypensation on the basis of the sub-soil rights to the hillock must therefore be negatived and the appeal allowed. In the result the decree of the High Court regarding the minerals in the land or quarry rights will be set aside and the judgement and order of the District Judge on that point restored.
